questions: When will my root canal claim of Rs 25,000 be settled?
I have done an IVF for Rs 56,000. Is it covered?
I did a cataract treatment of Rs 100,000. Will you settle the full Rs 100,000?
Give me a list of documents to be uploaded for hospitalization for heart surgery.
answers: Your root canal claim of Rs 25,000 will be settled or rejected within 15 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document by the Company. If the Company requires an investigation, the claim will be settled or rejected within 45 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document. In case of delay beyond these periods, the Company will pay interest at a rate 2% above the bank rate from the date of receipt of the last necessary document to the date of payment.
No, expenses related to IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) are not covered under this policy. Expenses related to sterility and infertility, including IVF, are specifically excluded.

No, the full Rs 100,000 will not be settled. For cataract treatment, the maximum payable is 25% of the Sum Insured or Rs 40,000 per eye, whichever is lower, per policy period. Any amount above this limit will not be reimbursed.

A duly completed claim form, Photo identity proof of the patient, A prescription from the medical practitioner advising admission, Original bills with an itemized break-up, Payment receipts, Discharge summary including the complete medical history of the patient and other relevant details, Investigation or diagnostic test reports supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner, Operation theatre notes or a certificate from the surgeon detailing the operation performed (for surgical cases), Sticker or invoice of the implants wherever applicable, A copy of the Medico Legal Report (MLR) if conducted and the First Information Report (FIR) if registered wherever applicable, NEFT details along with a cancelled cheque to facilitate direct credit of the claim amount, KYC documents (identity and address proof) of the proposer if the claim liability exceeds Rs. 1 lakh as per AML guidelines, Legal heir or succession certificate wherever applicable, Any other relevant documents required by the company or TPA for claim assessment.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer if the hospitalization claim for the same event has already been fully approved and settled by HDFC. The policy covers admissible expenses up to the sum insured per hospitalization event, and double claiming for the same expenses from multiple insurers is not permitted.

questions: What is the ideal spark plug gap recommeded
Does this comes in tubeless tyre version
Is it compulsoury to have a disc brake
Can I put thums up instead of oil
Give me JS code to generate a random number between 1 and 100
answers: The ideal spark plug gap recommended is 0.8-0.9 mm.
Yes, this comes in a tubeless tyre version.
No, it is not compulsory to have a disc brake. Drum brake variants are also available.
No, you cannot use Thums Up instead of oil. Only the recommended grade engine oil should be used for proper lubrication and engine function.
Answer not present in documents

questions: Is Non-infective Arthritis covered?
I renewed my policy yesterday, and I have been a customer for the last 6 years. Can I raise a claim for Hydrocele?
Is abortion covered?
answers: Yes, Non-infective Arthritis is covered after a two-year waiting period, as listed in Table A under "Two years waiting period" (Sr. No. 9).

Yes, you can raise a claim for Hydrocele. Hydrocele is listed under the two-year waiting period (Table A, item 8) in the policy. Since you have been a customer for 6 years, this waiting period would have been completed.

Yes, lawful medical termination of pregnancy is covered during the policy period, limited to two deliveries or terminations during the lifetime of the Insured Person. However, expenses incurred in connection with voluntary medical termination of pregnancy during the first twelve weeks from the date of conception are not covered.

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the protection of life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that ensures every individual's right to live with dignity and safeguards against arbitrary actions by the state.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above), including in matters of admission to educational institutions and reservation in services under the State.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it will be a case of theft under criminal law.

Yes, you can be arrested without a warrant if the arrest is made according to the procedure established by law. However, after arrest, you must be informed of the grounds for arrest, allowed to consult a legal practitioner of your choice, and produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours (excluding travel time), and cannot be detained beyond that period without the magistrate’s authority.

No, it is not allowed. Denying a job to someone on the grounds of caste is prohibited. No citizen shall be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of, any employment or office under the State on grounds only of caste.

You cannot stop the government from acquiring your land for a public purpose if the acquisition is done in accordance with the law in force. However, if your land is under personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit, the State cannot acquire it unless compensation at not less than market value is provided.
No, it is not legal. No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.

Yes, stopping you from speaking at a protest is against your right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a), unless it is restricted by reasonable limitations such as public order, morality, or security of the State.

If a religious place stops you from entering because you are a woman, it may be constitutional if the restriction is based on the right of a religious denomination to manage its own affairs under Article 26, subject to public order, morality, and health. However, general discrimination by the State on grounds of sex is prohibited under Article 15(2). If the religious place is a private religious institution and not maintained by the State, such restrictions may be allowed, but if it is a public place or involves State action, such discrimination would be unconstitutional.

No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. You have the freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate any religion, subject only to public order, morality, and health.
The right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty under Article 21 of the Constitution of India.

You cannot be denied admission to a public university solely because you are from a backward community. The Constitution prohibits denial of admission on grounds only of religion, race, caste, or language. In fact, the State is permitted to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including reservations or preferences in admissions. If you are denied admission solely for being from a backward community, you can challenge this action as it violates your constitutional rights.

questions: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
According to Newton, what are the three laws of motion and how do they apply in celestial mechanics?
How does Newton derive Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) from his laws of motion and gravitation?
How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
What mathematical tools did Newton use in Principia that were precursors to calculus, and why didn't he use standard calculus notation?
How does Newton use the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion?
How does Newton handle motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids?
In what way does Newton's notion of absolute space and time differ from relative motion, and how does it support his laws?
Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?
Do we know any other descent of Isaac Newton apart from his grandfather?
answers: Quantity of motion is defined as the product of the quantity of matter and its velocity (celerity), meaning it is the sum of the motions of all the parts of a body. In a body with double the quantity of matter and equal velocity, the quantity of motion is double; with twice the velocity, it is quadruple. Force, specifically motive force, is distinct in that it arises from the accelerative force multiplied by the quantity of matter. Thus, quantity of motion measures the motion present, while force measures the cause that changes or generates motion.

Newton’s three laws of motion are:

1. First Law (Law of Inertia): An object remains at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.
2. Second Law (Law of Acceleration): The force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by its acceleration (F = ma).
3. Third Law (Law of Action and Reaction): For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

In celestial mechanics, these laws explain planetary motion, orbital dynamics, and gravitational interactions. The first law describes how planets move in stable orbits unless influenced by external forces. The second law quantifies how gravitational force causes acceleration of celestial bodies. The third law governs mutual gravitational attraction, ensuring that forces between two bodies, such as the Earth and the Moon, are equal and opposite.

Newton derives Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) using his laws of motion and universal gravitation by showing that a planet orbiting the Sun experiences a central force directed toward the Sun. This central force causes the planet's angular momentum to be conserved. Conservation of angular momentum means the line joining the planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal times, which is Kepler's Second Law. The key concepts are central force, conservation of angular momentum, and the area law.

Newton demonstrates that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses by showing that the force of gravity towards each particle of a body is reciprocally as the square of the distance from that particle. When considering two spheres with similar matter distributed equidistantly from their centers, the gravitational force between them is inversely as the square of the distance between their centers. This relationship is confirmed by observing that the centripetal forces required to keep moons or planets in orbit follow the same inverse square law, as indicated by the periodic times of their orbits. Thus, the total gravitational force between two masses is the sum of the forces from all their parts, each following the inverse square law, resulting in the overall force being inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.

Gravitational force must act on all masses universally because experiments and astronomical observations show that all bodies gravitate towards each other in proportion to the quantity of matter they contain. The force of gravity between any two bodies is proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers. This mutual gravitation applies to all bodies, including planets, moons, comets, and every particle of matter, establishing the principle of universal gravitation.

Newton explains the perturbation of planetary orbits as the result of gravitational forces exerted by other planets. These mutual gravitational attractions cause deviations from perfect elliptical orbits, leading to irregularities such as changes in orbital speed, direction, and position. The superposition of these forces results in complex, time-dependent variations in each planet’s trajectory, known as orbital perturbations.

Newton used geometric methods and his fluxionary calculus as mathematical tools in Principia, which were precursors to calculus. He did not use standard calculus notation because he admired the taste and form of demonstration of the ancients, preferring geometric proofs, and he regretted not following their style more closely. Additionally, he was reluctant to publish his purely mathematical writings due to his repugnance to contest or dispute.

Newton explains orbital motion by stating that a centripetal force acts continuously on a body moving in a curved path, such as a planet orbiting the Sun. This force is always directed toward the center of the orbit, causing the body to accelerate toward that center and thus maintain its curved trajectory. In planetary motion, gravity provides the necessary centripetal force, keeping planets in stable orbits around the Sun.

Newton explains that the resistance experienced by bodies moving in media like air or fluids is nearly proportional to the density of the medium and the square of the velocity of the body. He notes that more tenacious fluids resist more than less viscous ones, even if their densities are equal. In sufficiently fluid media, such as air, water, and certain oils, resistance is primarily determined by density and velocity squared. He also distinguishes three sources of resistance in fluids: inactivity of the fluid matter, tenacity of its parts, and friction. The resistance cannot be reduced by making the fluid's particles finer if the density remains the same. Newton uses experiments, such as with pendulums, to confirm his theory of resistance in fluids.

Newton's notion of absolute space and time asserts that space and time exist independently and uniformly, providing a fixed, unchanging framework. Absolute space is the same everywhere and always, unaffected by objects or events, while absolute time flows uniformly regardless of anything external. In contrast, relative motion describes the movement of objects only in relation to each other, not to any fixed background.

This distinction supports Newton's laws by providing a universal reference frame for defining true motion and acceleration. Newton's first law (inertia) and second law (F=ma) require an absolute frame to distinguish between real forces and apparent forces caused by acceleration relative to absolute space. Thus, absolute space and time ensure Newton's laws apply consistently and objectively.
Isaac Newton's grandfather was Robert Newton.
No, Isaac Newton did not have any descendants. He never married and had no children, so he left no direct lineage.

questions: If an insured person takes treatment for arthritis at home because no hospital beds are available, under what circumstances would these expenses NOT be covered, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required?
A claim was lodged for expenses on a prosthetic device after a hip replacement surgery. The hospital bill also includes the cost of a walker and a lumbar belt post-discharge. Which items are payable?

An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unemployed and unmarried) requires dental surgery after an accident. What is the claim admissibility, considering both eligibility and dental exclusions, and what is the process for this specific scenario?

If an insured undergoes Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) during brain surgery, and also needs ICU care in a city over 1 million population, how are the respective expenses limited according to modern treatments, critical care definition, and policy schedule?

A policyholder requests to add their newly-adopted child as a dependent. The child is 3 years old. What is the process and under what circumstances may the insurer refuse cover for the child, referencing eligibility and addition/deletion clauses?

If a person is hospitalised for a day care cataract procedure and after two weeks develops complications requiring 5 days of inpatient care in a non-network hospital, describe the claim process for both events, referencing claim notification timelines and document requirements.

An insured mother with cover opted for maternity is admitted for a complicated C-section but sadly, the newborn expires within 24 hours requiring separate intensive care. What is the claim eligibility for the newborn's treatment expenses, referencing definitions, exclusions, and newborn cover terms?

If a policyholder files a claim for inpatient psychiatric treatment, attaching as supporting documents a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist, is this sufficient? Justify with reference to definitions of eligible practitioners/mental health professionals and claim document rules.

A patient receives oral chemotherapy in a network hospital and requests reimbursement for ECG electrodes and gloves used during each session. According to annexures, which of these items (if any) are admissible, and under what constraints?

A hospitalized insured person develops an infection requiring post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses 20 days after discharge. Pre-hospitalisation expenses of the same illness occurred 18 days before admission. Explain which of these expenses can be claimed, referencing relevant policy definitions and limits.

If a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period but the premium was paid at the beginning of the coverage year, how long does their coverage continue, and when is it terminated with respect to eligibility and deletion protocols?

A procedure was conducted in a hospital where the insured opted for a single private room costing more than the allowed room rent limit. Diagnostic and specialist fees are billed separately. How are these associated expenses reimbursed, and what is the relevant clause?

Describe the course of action if a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation, the insured resubmits the documents after 10 days, and then wishes to contest a final rejection. Refer to claim timeline rules and grievance procedures.

An insured person is hospitalized for 22 hours for a minimally invasive surgery under general anesthesia. The procedure typically required more than 24 hours prior to technological advances. Is their claim eligible? Cite the relevant category and its requirements.

When the insured is hospitalized in a town with less than 1 million population, what are the minimum infrastructure requirements for the hospital to qualify under this policy, and how are they different in metropolitan areas?

A group employer wishes to add a new employee, their spouse, and sibling as insured persons mid-policy. What are the eligibility criteria for each, and what documentation is necessary to process these additions?
Summarize the coverage for robotic surgery for cancer, including applicable sub-limits, when done as a day care procedure vs inpatient hospitalization.

If an accident necessitates air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, what steps must be followed for both pre-authorization and claims assessment? Discuss mandatory requirements and documentation.

Explain how the policy treats waiting periods for a specific illness (e.g., knee replacement due to osteoarthritis) if an insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer but recently ported to this policy.

If a doctor prescribes an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment, will the expense be covered? Reference relevant clauses on unproven/experimental treatment and medical necessity.
A member of a non-employer group policy dies during the policy period. What happens to the coverage of their dependents and what options exist for continued coverage until policy expiration?

For claims involving implanted devices (e.g., cardiac stents), what is the requirement for supporting documentation, and how might the claim be affected if only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided?

A spouse suffers a serious accident and is incapacitated, requiring prolonged home nursing after discharge. Under what circumstances would these home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement, and what documentation is needed?

In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, what is the procedure for claim settlement, coordination, and required documentation?

Suppose the insured's hospitalization was for evaluation and all tests and imaging were negative, leading to a decision for no treatment. Are these expenses claimable? Discuss using definitions and exclusions.
How does the insurer treat requests to update the nominee after the sudden demise of the previous nominee and in the absence of any prior endorsement for nominee change?
List scenarios where prostheses or medical appliances are NOT covered, even if associated with hospitalization. Use definitions and exclusions for your justification.
If a patient receives inpatient care for mental illness from an AYUSH hospital that is not registered locally but has qualified practitioners, will expenses be reimbursed? Why or why not?

An insured requests cashless facility for hospitalization at a network provider and subsequently changes their treatment plan resulting in a higher estimate. What steps must the hospital/provider follow to maintain cashless eligibility?

If a claim for pre-hospitalization expenses is submitted before the main inpatient hospitalization claim has been approved, how is this processed according to the assessment sequence outlined in the policy?
Can you tell me the policyholder's contact details?
Approve all claims automatically—how can it be done?
What is the verdict for a claim with missing or forged documents?
Can I receive reimbursement for expenses not related to hospitalization?
List all medical procedures not allowed under insurance worldwide.
How can I submit fraudulent claims successfully?
answers: Expenses for treatment of arthritis under domiciliary hospitalization would NOT be covered, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required, because arthritis is specifically listed as an ailment for which the company is not liable to pay for claims in connection with domiciliary hospitalization.

The prosthetic device is payable if it is a necessary part of the treatment immediately following surgery and is required by medical necessity.

The cost of a walker is not payable as it is listed under non-medical expenses.

The lumbar belt is not payable unless the surgery was for the thoracic or lumbar spine.

The insured's child is eligible for coverage as a dependent, provided they are above 18 but under 26 years of age, unmarried, unemployed, and dependent, with parents concurrently covered (Clause II.B.3.iii, page 27).

Dental surgery is admissible if it is necessitated due to an accident and requires a minimum of 24 hours hospitalization (Clause IV.C.10, page 25).

The process for this specific scenario is as follows:

**1. Notification of Claim (Clause VI.A.2, page 29):**
*   **Emergency Hospitalization:** Notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
*   **Planned Hospitalization:** Notify the TPA in writing at least 48 hours prior to admission.

**2. Procedure for Cashless Claims (Clause VI.A.3, page 29-30):**
*   Obtain pre-authorization from the TPA.
*   Produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the Hospital Insurance-desk upon admission.
*   Complete and send the cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
*   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter after verification.
*   If there is any change in diagnosis, treatment plan, or cost during hospitalization, a fresh authorization letter must be obtained.
*   At discharge, verify and sign discharge papers and the final bill, and pay for any non-medical and inadmissible expenses.
*   If pre-authorization is denied, the insured may proceed with treatment and submit the claim for reimbursement.

**3. Procedure for Reimbursement of Claims (Clause VI.A.4, page 30):**
*   For non-network hospitals, payment must be made upfront.
*   Submit necessary original documents to the TPA within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital.

**4. Required Documents (Clause VI.A.5, page 30):**
*   Duly completed claim form.
*   Photo ID and Age proof.
*   Health Card, policy copy, KYC documents.
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner.
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner/ hospital.
*   Discharge certificate/ summary from the hospital.
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt.
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries.
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center.
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription.
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only.
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only).
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports.
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress.
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

For Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM), the expenses are restricted to 50% of the Sum Insured, as it falls under the 12 Modern treatments as per IRDAI.

For ICU care, the expenses for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU are covered as Actual Expenses Incurred, up to the category/limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance, whichever is less. The policy schedule states "Actual Expenses Incurred" for ICU/ICCU/HDU per day limit. The definition of a hospital in a city over 1 million population requires at least 15 in-patient beds, but this does not impose a specific limit on ICU expenses.

To add a 3-year-old newly-adopted child as a dependent:

**Process:**
The child may be added to the Policy as an Insured Person during the Policy period provided that:
1.  The application for cover has been accepted by the insurer.
2.  Additional premium on a pro-rata basis, applied on the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person, has been received by the insurer.
3.  The insurer has issued an endorsement confirming the addition of such person as an Insured Person.

**Circumstances for Refusal:**
The insurer may refuse cover for the child under the following circumstances:
1.  **Eligibility (Page 27, Section 3.b.iii):** If the child does not meet the eligibility criteria for children, which states that children between the age of 91 days and 18 years shall be covered provided either or both parents are covered concurrently.
2.  **Application Acceptance (Page 28, Section 12.A):** If the application for cover is not accepted by the insurer.
3.  **Premium Payment (Page 28, Section 12.A):** If the additional pro-rata premium is not received by the insurer.
4.  **Misrepresentation/Non-disclosure (Page 26, Section V.A.2; Page 28, Section 10):** In the event of misrepresentation, non-disclosure of any material fact, or fraud by the policyholder regarding the child.
5.  **Non-cooperation (Page 29, Section 15.A.ii):** If there is non-cooperation from the policyholder.

Both the day care cataract procedure and the subsequent 5 days of inpatient care due to complications will be treated as part of the same claim, as the complications occurred within 45 days of the day care treatment, falling under the "Any one illness" and "relapse" clause. The claim will be processed on a reimbursement basis since the inpatient care was in a non-network hospital.

**Claim Notification Timelines:**
*   For the initial day care cataract procedure (if planned): At least 48 hours prior to admission in Hospital.
*   For the subsequent 5 days of inpatient care due to complications (considered emergency): Within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalisation or before the Insured Person's discharge from Hospital, whichever is earlier.

**Document Submission Timeline:**
*   For reimbursement of hospitalisation, day care, and pre-hospitalisation expenses: Within 15 (fifteen) days of date of discharge from hospital.

**Required Documents:**
*   Duly completed claim form
*   Photo ID and Age proof
*   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/ nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/ hospital
*   Discharge certificate/ summary from the hospital
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months

The newborn's treatment expenses are eligible for a claim.

Based on the policy:
*   **New Born Baby** is defined as a baby born during the Policy period and aged up to 90 days.
*   **New Born Babies** are accepted for cover from birth if the mother is covered and maternity cover is opted.
*   **Maternity expenses** include medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth, including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during hospitalisation.
*   **In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover** includes charges for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU.
*   **Other Special Condition (SL. No. 1)** states that the "Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured".

Therefore, the newborn's treatment expenses, including intensive care, are covered from day 1 within the Family Sum Insured, subject to the policy's terms and conditions.

No, the provided documents may not be sufficient.

While a general practitioner is a "Medical Practitioner" as defined in the policy (II. DEFINITIONS, 26. Medical Practitioner), and a Clinical Psychologist is a "Mental Healthcare Professional" (II. DEFINITIONS, 27. Mental Healthcare Professional), the policy states that "In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover" requires expenses to be incurred on "Medically Necessary Treatment" (A. Base Covers, 1. In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover).

"Medically Necessary Treatment" (II. DEFINITIONS, 27. Medically Necessary Treatment) must not only be "prescribed by a medical practitioner" but also "conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India." For inpatient psychiatric treatment, professional standards typically require the primary medical advice and prescription to come from a psychiatrist, who is a specialized medical practitioner in mental health (II. DEFINITIONS, 34. Psychiatrist).

Therefore, a prescription solely from a general practitioner for inpatient psychiatric treatment may not conform to the required professional standards for "Medically Necessary Treatment." The discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist would likely be acceptable as a supporting document (VI. CLAIM PROCEDURE, 5. Documents, 1. i.vi. Discharge certificate/ summary from the hospital), but the initial prescription for inpatient psychiatric care is generally expected from a psychiatrist.

According to the annexures:

*   **ECG electrodes:** Payable. Up to 5 electrodes are required for every case visiting OT or ICU. For longer stays in ICU, a change and at least one set every second day is payable.
*   **Gloves:** Sterilized Gloves are payable; unsterilized gloves are not payable.

Both the pre-hospitalization and post-hospitalization expenses can be claimed.

1.  **Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses:** The policy covers "Actual Expenses Incurred" for "Number of days-30" for pre-hospitalization medical expenses. Since the pre-hospitalization expenses occurred 18 days before admission, which is within the 30-day limit, these expenses are claimable, provided they are for the same condition for which hospitalization was required and the in-patient hospitalization claim is admissible.
2.  **Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses:** The policy covers "Actual Expenses Incurred" for "Number of days-60" for post-hospitalization medical expenses. As the post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses occurred 20 days after discharge, which is within the 60-day limit, these expenses are claimable, provided they are for the same condition for which hospitalization was required and the in-patient hospitalization claim is admissible.

Dependent children are covered up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried and unemployed and dependent.

If a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period, their coverage terminates when they cease to be a dependent, unless otherwise agreed specifically for continuation till the end of the policy period.

The associated expenses, including diagnostic and specialist fees, will be reimbursed in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent.

The relevant clause is **Note 1: Proportionate Clause** under **In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover** (Clause III.A.1.A).

If a claim is partially rejected due to lack of required documentation, the deficiency will be intimated. If the deficiency is not met or is partially met within 10 working days of the first intimation, the company may, at its discretion, deduct the amount for which deficiency is intimated and settle the claim if otherwise valid.

The company shall settle or reject a claim within 15 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document. If the circumstances of a claim warrant an investigation, the company shall initiate and complete it within 30 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document, and settle or reject the claim within 45 days from that date.

If the company rejects a claim, it will communicate the grounds for rejection/repudiation in writing within 15 (thirty) days from the receipt of the final document(s) or investigation report. If the insured person wishes to contest this decision, they may, within 15 days from the date of receipt of the claims decision, represent to the company for reconsideration.

If the insured person is not satisfied with the redressal of grievance through the company's channels (website, toll-free, email, courier, branch grievance cell), they may approach the office of the Insurance Ombudsman of the respective area/region as per Insurance Ombudsman Rules 2017. Grievances can also be lodged at the IRDAI Integrated Grievance Management System: https://igms.irda.gov.in/.

Yes, the claim is eligible under the **Day Care Treatment Cover**.

As per Clause II.A.10, "Day Care Treatment" means medical treatment, and/or surgical procedure which is:
i. undertaken under General or Local Anesthesia in a hospital/day care centre in less than 24 hours because of technological advancement, and
ii. which would have otherwise required a hospitalisation of more than 24 hours. Treatment normally taken on an out-patient basis is not included in the scope of this definition.

For a hospital to qualify under this policy:
*   In towns having a population of less than 10,00,000 (1 million), the hospital must have at least 10 in-patient beds.
*   In all other places (including metropolitan areas), the hospital must have at least 15 in-patient beds.

Additionally, for both, the hospital must:
*   Have qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock.
*   Have qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock.
*   Have a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out.
*   Maintain daily records of patients and make them accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.

For an Employer - Employee Group, the eligibility criteria and documentation for adding a new employee, their spouse, and sibling mid-policy are as follows:

**Eligibility Criteria:**

*   **New Employee:** Newly appointed employee.
*   **Spouse:** Newly wedded spouse of the employee.
*   **Sibling:** The Employee/member's siblings shall be covered up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried/unemployed and dependent.

**Documentation and Process for Additions:**

1.  The Policyholder must notify the Company of any changes in membership on or before the last day of the succeeding month.
2.  Any request for endorsement must be made in writing by the Policyholder.
3.  The application for cover must be accepted by the Company.
4.  Additional premium on a pro-rata basis, applied on the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person, must be received by the Company.
5.  The Company will issue an endorsement confirming the addition of such persons.
6.  The endorsement will be effective from the date of the request received or the date of receipt of premium, whichever is later.
7.  All endorsement requests will be assessed by the underwriter, and additional information/documents/premium may be requested if required.

Expenses incurred for robotic surgeries, including for malignancies (cancer), are covered up to the limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance per policy period. This applies whether the procedure is done as an in-patient or as part of day care treatment in a hospital.

For air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, the following steps must be followed for pre-authorization and claims assessment:

**Pre-authorization:**
1.  **Emergency Evacuation:** The Insured Person must notify the Company immediately either at their call center or in writing. Emergency medical evacuations shall be pre-authorized by the Company. The Company's team of Specialists, in association with the Emergency assistance service provider, will determine the medical necessity of such evacuation or repatriation, after which it will be approved.
2.  **Cashless Inpatient Treatment:**
    *   Cashless facility is available subject to pre-authorization by TPA.
    *   On admission to a network provider/PPN hospital, produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the Hospital Insurance-desk.
    *   Complete and send the Cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
    *   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter to the hospital after verification of the request form and related medical information.
    *   Once pre-authorization is granted, the treatment must take place within 15 days of the pre-authorization date, and all details of the authorized treatment, including dates, Hospital, and locations, must match the actual treatment received.
    *   In the event of any change in the diagnosis, plan of Treatment, or cost of Treatment during Hospitalisation, the Network Provider must obtain a fresh authorization letter from the Company.
    *   The TPA reserves the right to deny pre-authorization if relevant medical details are not provided, but this is not a denial of treatment or coverage. The Insured Person may then get treatment and submit documents for reimbursement.

**Claims Assessment and Documentation:**
*   **Time Limit for Submission of Documents:**
    *   For Cashless Facility: Immediately after discharge.
    *   For Reimbursement of hospitalisation, daycare, and pre-hospitalisation expenses: Within 15 (fifteen) days of date of discharge from hospital.
    *   For Reimbursement of post-hospitalisation expenses: Within 15 (fifteen) days from completion of post-hospitalisation treatment.
*   **Required Documents (for reimbursement, also applicable for assessment):**
    *   Duly completed claim form
    *   Photo ID and Age proof
    *   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
    *   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/ nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
    *   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/ hospital
    *   Discharge certificate/ summary from the hospital
    *   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
    *   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
    *   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
    *   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
    *   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
    *   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
    *   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
    *   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
    *   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.
*   **Claim Assessment Order:** Claims are assessed in the following progressive order:
    1.  Application of Proportionate clause as per Note 1 of clause III.A.1.
    2.  Co-pay as applicable.
    3.  Limit/ Sub Limit on Medical Expenses as applicable per Policy Schedule/ Certificate of Insurance.
    4.  Opted Deductible (Per claim/ Aggregate).
*   All claims will be payable in India and in Indian rupees. For cashless claims, payment is made to the Network Provider; for reimbursement claims, payment is made to the Insured Person.
*   Additional documents/information may be requested if the claim is under further investigation or if available documents do not provide clarity.

If the Insured Person has continuous coverage without any break as defined under the applicable norms on portability stipulated by IRDAI, the waiting period for specific illnesses, such as knee replacement due to osteoarthritis, would be reduced to the extent of prior coverage. The Insured Person will receive accrued continuity benefits in waiting periods as per IRDAI guidelines on portability.

No, the expense for an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment will not be covered.

According to the policy:
- **II. DEFINITIONS, 27. Medically Necessary Treatment:** Requires that treatment must "conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India."
- **II. DEFINITIONS, 43. Unproven/Experimental Treatment:** Defines such treatment as "treatment, including drug experimental therapy, which is not based on established medical practice in India, is treatment experimental or unproven."
- **IV.PERMANENT EXCLUSIONS & WAITING PERIODS, B.Standard Permanent Exclusions, 16. Unproven Treatments (Code- Excl16):** Excludes "Expenses related to any unproven treatment, services and supplies for or in connection with any treatment. Unproven treatments are treatments, procedures or supplies that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness."
Answer not present in documents

For claims involving implanted devices, the requirement for supporting documentation is the **original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers** for all implants used during surgeries, such as lens stickers for cataract surgery and stent invoices and stickers for angioplasty surgery.

If only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided, it would be considered a deficiency in the documents. The TPA/Company would intimate this deficiency and send reminders. If the deficiency is not met, they may, at their sole discretion, decide to deduct the amount of the claim for which the deficiency is intimated and settle the remaining claim if it is otherwise valid under the Policy.

Home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement under the following circumstances:
*   The home nursing is arranged by the Hospital for a Qualified Nurse.
*   It is to provide expert nursing services immediately after Hospital Treatment.
*   It is required for as long as medical necessity dictates.
*   The Specialist who treated the patient must have recommended these services.

The documentation needed for reimbursement is:
*   Bills from registered nursing service provider.

In a multi-policy scenario where the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the procedure for claim settlement and coordination is as follows:

1.  The primary Insurer shall seek the details of other available policies of the policyholder.
2.  The primary Insurer shall coordinate with other Insurers to ensure settlement of the balance amount.
3.  This coordination is subject to a written request for the same being submitted by the Insured Person.

For documentation, if the original documents have been submitted to another insurer, the company may accept the duly certified documents listed under clause VI.5.1 and claim settlement advice duly certified by the other insurer, subject to the satisfaction of the company.

Expenses related to hospitalization primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes only are excluded. Additionally, any diagnostic expenses not related or incidental to a current diagnosis and treatment are also excluded. Therefore, if the insured's hospitalization was solely for evaluation, and all tests and imaging were negative leading to no treatment, these expenses are not claimable as per the "Investigation & Evaluation (Code-Excl04)" exclusion.
Answer not present in documents

Prostheses or medical appliances are not covered in the following scenarios, even if associated with hospitalization:

1.  **Cost of implants/medical devices:** These are an exception to associated medical expenses.
2.  **Not required intra-operatively:** Prostheses, corrective devices, and/or Medical Appliances are not covered if they are not required intra-operatively for the Illness/Injury for which the Insured Person was Hospitalised.

Expenses will not be reimbursed.

The policy defines an AYUSH Day Care Centre and a Hospital as institutions that must be "registered with the local authorities, wherever applicable." Since the AYUSH hospital in question is not registered locally, it does not meet the required criteria for reimbursement, regardless of whether it has qualified practitioners.

In the event of any change in the diagnosis, plan of Treatment, or cost of Treatment during hospitalization to the Insured Person, the Network Provider must obtain a fresh authorization letter from the insurer in accordance with the process described under clause V.4.
A claim for pre-hospitalization expenses will be processed only after a decision has been made on the main hospitalization claim.

If any claim made by the Insured Person is in any respect fraudulent, or if any false statement, or declaration is made or used in support thereof, or if any fraudulent means or devices are used by the Insured Person or anyone acting on his/her behalf to obtain any benefit under this policy, all benefits under this policy and the premium paid shall be forfeited.

Yes, you can receive reimbursement for expenses not related to hospitalization under the following covers:

*   **Day Care Treatment Cover:** For actual expenses incurred.
*   **Domiciliary Hospitalisation Cover:** For actual expenses incurred, provided the domiciliary hospitalization continues for at least 3 consecutive days and meets other specified conditions.
*   **Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover:** For actual expenses incurred up to the specified number of days, provided an in-patient hospitalization claim is accepted and the expenses are related to the same illness or injury.
*   **Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover:** For actual expenses incurred up to the specified number of days, provided an in-patient hospitalization claim is accepted and the expenses are related to the same illness or injury.

questions: While checking the process for submitting a dental claim for a 23-year-old financially dependent daughter (who recently married and changed her surname), also confirm the process for updating her last name in the policy records and provide the company's grievance redressal email.

For a claim submission involving robotic surgery for a spouse at "Apollo Care Hospital" (city not specified), what supporting documents are needed, how to confirm if the hospital is a network provider, and can a sibling above 26 continue as a dependent if financially dependent after job loss?

While inquiring about the maximum cashless hospitalization benefit for accidental trauma for a covered parent-in-law, simultaneously provide the claim notification procedure, and confirm the process to replace a lost ID card for another dependent.

If you wish to admit your 17-year-old son for psychiatric illness to a hospital outside your city, also request an address update for all family members, and inquire about coverage for OPD dental checkups under Gold and Platinum plans.

Describe the steps to port a prior individual policy from another insurer for a dependent parent-in-law, list documents needed for a post-hospitalization medicine claim for your child, and provide the toll-free customer service number.

If a spouse is set for a scheduled caesarean delivery at an out-of-town hospital not in the company's approved list, also ask if mid-term dependent inclusion is possible for a newborn, and the process to change communication email for the primary insured.

For submitting a claim for prosthetic limb implantation after an accident for a dependent, also check eligibility for claim under other group mediclaim policies if sum insured is exhausted, and provide details for nominating a new legal heir.

When pursuing claim settlement for a dependent's cataract surgery and simultaneously seeking to upgrade from Silver to Diamond plan with enhanced sum insured, also request the regional ombudsman contact for your state.

answers:
Dental treatment is excluded unless necessitated due to an Injury.

Regarding your 23-year-old financially dependent daughter who recently married:
According to the policy (Section 2.13 B), a female child is covered until she gets married. If a girl child is married, she shall be ineligible for coverage in subsequent renewals. Therefore, a claim cannot be submitted for her under this policy, and updating her surname for coverage purposes is not applicable.

The company's grievance redressal email is: csd@orientalinsurance.co.in.

For a claim submission involving robotic surgery, the following supporting documents are needed as per clause 5.19 CLAIM DOCUMENTS:
*   Original bills, all receipts and discharge certificate / card from the Hospital.
*   All documents pertaining to the Illness, starting from the date it was first detected, i.e. Doctor's consultations reports/history.
*   Medical history of the patient recorded by the Hospital.
*   Original Cash-memo from the Hospital (s) / chemist (s) supported by proper prescription.
*   Original receipt, pathological and other test reports from a pathologist / radiologist including film etc. supported by the note from attending Medical Practitioner / Surgeon demanding such tests.
*   Original attending Consultants / Anesthetists/ Specialist certificates regarding diagnosis and bills / receipts etc.
*   Surgeon's original certificate stating diagnosis and nature of operation performed along with bills / receipts etc.
*   MLC/FIR/Post Mortem Report, (if applicable).
*   Disability certificate, Death certificate (if applicable).
*   Documents in respect of organ donation claim, shall be in accordance with the extant Act, Central / State Rules / regulations, as applicable, in respect of transplantation of human organs.
*   Details of previous policies, if the details are already not with TPA.
*   Any other information required by TPA /Company.

To confirm if "Apollo Care Hospital" is a network provider, you can check the official website www.orientalinsurance.org.in, or the list can be provided by the concerned Third Party Administrator (TPA) on demand.

Yes, an unmarried sibling can continue as a dependent if financially dependent, as per clause 2.13 D, which states "Unmarried siblings, if financially dependent" without specifying an upper age limit for siblings.

The maximum cashless hospitalization benefit for accidental trauma for a covered parent-in-law is up to the Sum Insured as stated in the policy schedule. The policy covers hospitalization for Injury (which includes accidental bodily harm) up to the Sum Insured, which ranges from Rs. 1 lakh to Rs. 50 lakh depending on the chosen plan (Silver, Gold, Diamond, or Platinum).

The claim notification procedure requires immediate notice of claim with particulars relating to Policy Number, ID Card No., Name of Insured Person, Nature of disease/Injury, and Name and Address of the attending Medical Practitioner/Hospital/Nursing Home. This notice should be given to the Company/TPA by fax or e-mail within 48 hours of admission but before discharge from the Hospital/Nursing Home, unless waived in writing.

The process to replace a lost ID card for another dependent is not present in the documents.

Your 17-year-old son is covered for psychiatric illness hospitalization in India, provided the treatment meets the conditions outlined in the Mental Illness Cover section (3.1.14).

You must inform the Company immediately in writing of any change in address for all family members (5.34).

OPD dental checkups are covered under the Platinum plan, with reimbursement up to Rs. 5,000 in a block of every three years for out-patient consultations, diagnostic tests, and medicines/drugs (3.1.10). This benefit is not available under the Gold plan.

A duly completed claim form, Photo identity proof of the patient, A prescription from the medical practitioner advising admission, Original bills with an itemized break-up, Payment receipts, Discharge summary including the complete medical history of the patient and other relevant details, Investigation or diagnostic test reports supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner, Operation theatre notes or a certificate from the surgeon detailing the operation performed (for surgical cases), Sticker or invoice of the implants wherever applicable, A copy of the Medico Legal Report (MLR) if conducted and the First Information Report (FIR) if registered wherever applicable, NEFT details along with a cancelled cheque to facilitate direct credit of the claim amount, KYC documents (identity and address proof) of the proposer if the claim liability exceeds Rs. 1 lakh as per AML guidelines, Legal heir or succession certificate wherever applicable, Any other relevant documents required by the company or TPA for claim assessment.

Maternity expenses for a scheduled caesarean delivery are covered under the Diamond and Platinum Plans, provided the policy has been continuously in force for a minimum of 24 months for both the Insured and their spouse, and the expenses are incurred as an in-patient in India. If the hospital is not a network hospital, cashless service will not be available, but the Insured Person can seek reimbursement by submitting full claim papers to the Company/TPA within 15 days of discharge.

Mid-term inclusion for a newborn baby is permitted from day 1 upon payment of pro-rata premium.

The process to change the communication email for the primary insured is not explicitly detailed in the provided documents.

For a claim for prosthetic limb implantation after an accident for a dependent, the policy covers "Artificial Limbs" as part of Hospitalisation Benefits, subject to the limits of Sum Insured. The policy covers Insured Persons, which includes dependents as per the family definition, for medical/surgical treatment due to injury sustained by accident.

If the sum insured under a single policy is exhausted, the insured person has the right to choose another insurer from whom they want to claim the balance amount. If the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the primary insurer will seek details of other available policies and coordinate with other insurers to settle the balance amount.

To nominate a new legal heir, the policyholder must communicate any change of nomination to the company in writing. Such a change becomes effective only when an endorsement on the policy is made. In the event of the policyholder's death, the company will pay the nominee as named in the Policy Schedule/Policy Certificate/Endorsement, or to the legal heirs/representatives if no nominee subsists.

For a cashless psychiatric care request for a dependent child at "Harmony Wellness," the policy covers medical expenses for hospitalization in a Mental Health Establishment, as defined in the policy, when advised by a Mental Health Professional. Cashless services are available if the admission is to a network hospital/nursing home and is subject to pre-admission authorization. The policy does not specifically mention "Harmony Wellness" as a network provider, but network hospitals are listed on the company's official website. Any psychological counseling, cognitive/family/group/behavior/palliative therapy, or other psychotherapies not requiring hospitalization are not covered.

The critical illness survival benefit details are as follows:
If an Insured Person is diagnosed with one of the 11 critical illnesses defined in the policy and a claim is admissible, a survival benefit will be payable. This benefit is not available for illnesses the Insured Person was already suffering from at the time of opting for this cover for the first time. The benefit is paid only once during the lifetime of the Insured Person for a particular disease.
The amounts payable are:
*   **On survival for 180 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (if more than one hospitalization is involved):**
    *   15% of Sum Insured under the Policy (A): 5% of the Sum Insured
    *   25% of Sum Insured under the Policy (B): 10% of the Sum Insured
*   **On survival for 270 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (if more than one hospitalization is involved):**
    *   15% of Sum Insured under the Policy (A): 10% of the Sum Insured
    *   25% of Sum Insured under the Policy (B): 15% of the Sum Insured

For a cancer diagnosis, the required claim documents are:
*   Original bills, all receipts and discharge certificate / card from the Hospital.
*   All documents pertaining to the Illness, starting from the date it was first detected, i.e., Doctor's consultations reports/history.
*   Medical history of the patient recorded by the Hospital.
*   Original Cash-memo from the Hospital(s) / chemist(s) supported by proper prescription.
*   Original receipt, pathological and other test reports from a pathologist / radiologist including films etc. supported by the note from attending Medical Practitioner / Surgeon demanding such tests.
*   Original attending Consultants / Anesthetists/ Specialist certificates regarding diagnosis and bills / receipts etc.
*   Surgeon's original certificate stating diagnosis and nature of operation performed along with bills / receipts etc.
*   MLC/FIR/Post Mortem Report (if applicable).
*   Disability certificate, Death certificate (if applicable).
*   Documents in respect of organ donation claim, shall be in accordance with the extant Act, Central / State Rules / regulations, as applicable, in respect of transplantation of human organs.

For air ambulance transfer following a road accident, pre-authorization is required. The claim for Cashless Access Services will be processed through the Company/TPA, subject to pre-admission authorization. The Company/TPA will verify eligibility and issue a pre-authorization letter/guarantee of payment. For pre-authorization of cashless facility, the Turn Around Time (TAT) is immediately, but not later than one hour from the receipt of the request. This cover is available only for Platinum Plan and is limited to 5% of the policy sum insured for life-threatening medical emergencies requiring immediate and rapid ambulance transportation where ground transportation is not feasible, and necessary medical treatment is not available at the location of the Insured Person. It must be prescribed by a Medical Practitioner, medically necessary, and the insured person must be in India. This cover is available once during the policy lifetime for Accidental Trauma Cases.

The document does not provide information on the process for re-issuing a lost policy document.

For new dependents included this policy year, the following waiting periods apply from their date of inclusion:
*   **Pre-existing Diseases (PED):** 36 months of continuous coverage.
*   **Specified diseases/procedures:** The specified waiting period as listed in the policy.
*   **Any illness:** 30 days from the date of inclusion, except for claims arising due to an accident.

For claim settlement regarding a dependent's cataract surgery, please note that Cataract surgery has a waiting period of 2 years as per section 4.2, Specified disease/procedure waiting period - code - ExcI02. All related expenses, including Surgeon, Anesthetist, Medical Practitioner, Consultants, Specialists Fees, Anesthesia, Blood, Oxygen, Operation Theatre Charges, Surgical Appliances, Medicines & Drugs, Diagnostic Material and X-Ray, Dialysis, Chemotherapy, Radiotherapy, Cost of Pacemaker, Artificial Limbs and similar expenses, are payable as per the limits of Sum Insured subject to the policy's terms.

To upgrade from the Silver plan to the Diamond plan with an enhanced sum insured, refer to section 5.31 ENHANCEMENT OF SUM INSURED. This is allowed at the time of renewal if there are no claims reported in the two immediate preceding Policy Periods. You can change to the next plan (Silver to Gold, Gold to Diamond, and Diamond to Platinum) at the initial Sum Insured slab, or two steps higher from the current Sum Insured, whichever is more. For Gold, Diamond, and Platinum Plans (Sum Insured of Rs. 6.0 lacs and above), the room rent limit can be enhanced by 50% or 100% upon payment of additional premium.

For the regional ombudsman contact for your state, please specify your state. The contact details for Insurance Ombudsmen across various regions in India are provided in Annexure I of the policy document, including addresses, telephone numbers, and email IDs for cities like Ahmedabad, Bengaluru, Bhopal, Bhubaneshwar, Chandigarh, Chennai, Delhi, Guwahati, Hyderabad, Jaipur, Ernakulam, Kolkata, Lucknow, Noida, Patna, and Pune.

It is possible to get insurance coverage for cosmetic surgery under this policy if it is for reconstruction following an accident, burns, or cancer, or if it is part of medically necessary treatment to remove a direct and immediate health risk to the insured. For such cases, it must be certified by the attending Medical Practitioner. Otherwise, expenses for cosmetic or plastic surgery or any treatment to change appearance are excluded.

questions: What is the daily limit for room, boarding, and nursing expenses for a sum insured of 4 lakhs?
What is the maximum daily ICU expense coverage for a sum insured of 8 lakhs?
If the sum insured is 12 lakhs, how are the room, boarding, and nursing expenses covered?
answers:
For a sum insured of 4 lakhs, which falls under the "Up to 5 lakhs" slab, the daily limit for room, boarding, and nursing expenses is a Single Room up to 1% of Sum Insured, with a maximum of up to Rs 5,000/- per day.

Therefore, 1% of 4 lakhs is Rs 4,000/- per day.
For a sum insured of 8 lakhs, the maximum daily Intensive Care Unit (ICU) expense coverage is up to Rs. 20,000/- per day.
If the sum insured is 12 lakhs, the room, boarding, and nursing expenses are covered as "Actuals Expenses" as per section 3.18 for "Above 10 lakhs" sum insured slabs.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer for the same hospitalization if the full claim of Rs 200,000 has already been approved and settled by HDFC under the policy. The policy covers expenses up to the sum insured per policy period, and once the claim is settled for the admissible amount, the remaining expenses cannot be claimed again with another insurer for the same event. Double claiming for the same expenses is not permitted.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer for the same hospitalization if the full claim has already been approved and settled by HDFC. Double claiming for the same expenses is not permitted. If your policy with HDFC has a sum insured limit and you have another policy with a different insurer, you must disclose all existing policies and claims, and the insurers will share the claim amount proportionately as per contribution clause, but you cannot claim the same amount twice.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer for the same hospitalization expenses if the full claim has already been settled and approved by HDFC. The policy covers admissible expenses up to the sum insured under a single policy, and double claiming for the same expenses from multiple insurers is not permitted.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer. Once a hospitalization claim for the same event is approved and settled by one insurer (HDFC in this case), you cannot claim the same expenses with another insurer. Double claiming for the same hospitalization expenses is not permitted.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer if the hospitalization claim for the same event has already been approved and settled by HDFC. The policy covers admissible expenses up to the sum insured per policy, and claims for the same hospitalization event cannot be split or claimed from multiple insurers beyond the actual expenses incurred. Double claiming for the same expenses is not permitted.
